Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Studies on Catalytic Asymmetric C-H Amination of Alkenes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Radhey S. Srivastava and Dr. Siva Murru. Prof. Radhey S. Srivastava is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at University of Louisiana at Lafayette. Prof. Srivastava's group is developing novel catalytic systems to convert simple hydrocarbons to value-added products. The main goal of the proposed research is to design and develop novel catalytic systems for the production of valuable molecules that are of industrial significance. The method uses copper catalysts with chiral ligands. The demand for chiral allyl amines has escalated sharply in recent years, driven by the demands in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, flavors, fragrances, and materials. In addition, these catalytic methods are potential useful for the total synthesis of bioactive molecules and chiral drugs. The researchers have introduced comprehensive educational and outreach programs associated with intellectual and economic development. Professor Srivastava's group has been working at the interface of organic, organometallics, and catalysis chemistry.

This research addresses the development of a direct catalytic asymmetric amination of simple (non-functionalized) allylic carbon-hydrogen (C-H) substrates using hydroxylamines as aminating agents. The prior art on this field used oxidative amination to make chiral N-hydroxy allyl amines that require additional methods to make chiral allyl amines. The main aim is to find suitable catalytic systems that would deliver the chiral allyl amines with high yields and enantioselectivities. This approach includes rational design and synthesis of new chiral ligands and complexes. The research project screens the catalysts under various reaction conditions while varying solvents, temperature, and additives. The next objective is to explore the synthetic applications to access valuable chemicals such as chiral beta-alkyl N-aryl Aza Baylis-Hillman (ABH) adducts, beta-amino esters and beta-lactams, as well as bioactive molecules such as hydroxymethyl docetaxel fragment, Ezetimibe, and Vigabatrin. Another objective is to address mechanistic aspects of the reaction and provide a better understanding of the reaction pathway and the catalytic activity. This objective helps to develop new catalysts and novel synthetic methods. Professor Srivastava's program enhances public awareness of the importance of chemical sciences. Undergraduates, K-12 students, and high school teachers are exposed to cutting-edge science related to chemical catalysis through summer research and teacher training workshops. The education outreach initiatives involve the inclusion of women and underrepresented groups and strengthen competitiveness by promoting enhancement programs such as LSAMP and McNair program to retain students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report ? NSF Award# 1566561.

 Project Title: Studies on Catalytic Asymmetric C-H-amination of Alkenes.

 Recipient Organization: University of Louisiana at Lafayette

 

Project/Grant Period: 08/1/2016-09/30/20 (includes one year plus no cost extension).

PI: Radhey Srivastava

            The project established the design and implementation of a novel asymmetric amination of simple (non-functionalized) allylic C-H substrates using hydroxylamines as aminating agents, which was not known so far. The earlier known methods require an additional method/step to make chiral allyl amines. Asymmetric allylic amination (AAA) has a wide applicability in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, flavors, fragrances, and materials direct approach to make the chiral amines and bioactive molecules better accessible to the scientific community. We were successful in our endeavor and published/submitted two research publications, (i) Rahul Kumar Rajmani Singh, Tolga N.V. Karsili, Radhey Srivastava, ?Copper-catalyzed enantioselective direct α-C-H amination of β-dicarbonyl derivatives with aryl hydroxylamines and mechanistic insights?, Molecular Catalysis, 2020, 493, 111067, and (ii) Bhanudas D. Mokar, Ramesh Bista, Frank Fronczek,Jean Le Bras, Dominique Harakat, Siva Murru, Kenneth M. Nicholas, Radhey S. Srivastava, Copper-Catalyzed Asymmetric Allylic C-H Amination of Alkenes using N-Arylhydroxylamines

(Chemical science, submitted December 11, 2020).

 

In addition, the PI has given four international presentations and was a keynote speaker in invited presentations at conferences/seminars during this period.

 

Unpublished results

1.      Attempted synthesis of chiral amino oxindole.  Unfortunately, our effort to synthesize chiral oxindole was not fruitful. When we treated oxindole with various chiral ligands (e.g. BINAM, box, pypox) and aryl hydroxylamine in the presence of metal catalysts (Co(II) mesoporphorine , Zn(OAc)2-TEA and Cu(Otf)2 and phenanthroline), all produced achiral amine in over 98% yield.

2.      Synthesis of chiral α -amino carbonyl compounds using aniline as nitrogen donor. Inexpensive aniline is commercially available. We anticipate that the oxidation of aniline in situ will general PhNO, which is proven active aminating agent. We attempted the synthesis of Cu(I)-catalyzed chiral α -amino carbonyl compounds using aniline as reaction partner was also successful but with low ee compared to PhNO (48-58% ee).

3.      Synthesis of chiral Aza Baylis-Hilman (ABH) adducts. We developed an asymmetric version of ABH reaction but in low enantiomeric excess (ee) and yields (15-23% ee).

 

4.      Synthesis of chiral Dienes and Triene. No method has been reported for the chiral allylic C?H amination of 1,3-dienes to prepare aminomethyl-1,3dienes, which are also useful intermediates in organic synthesis.  We applied the optimized reaction condition of AAA to extend the scope for the amination of dienes and trienes and successfully synthesized chiral aminomethyl-1,3dienes/trienes, though in low ee (35-50% ee).

 

An important way my group is contributing to University of Louisiana Lafayette undergraduate students? advancement is through their involvement in undergraduate research. Most of the undergraduate students in my group have been female, and there have been several minorities as well. The vast majority were students who were the ﬁrst to go to college in their family. This presents a unique opportunity for us to make a diﬀerence and show them opportunities that they are not aware exist. For example, most of these students never consider the possibility of going to graduate school and they are unaware of the fact that one can study for a PhD in Chemistry without having to pay. Educating them of these possibilities is very important. I have learned through my years at UL-L, there is extra pressure from their environment and family to ﬁnish college and get a job rather than continue their education. Another problem is that the students often underestimate their capabilities and potential. For example, a big obstacle is that they do not feel at home when being around other scientists. To overcome this, I send them to meetings where they can meet other scientists, but also meet other students who have similar interests and plans. Networks and conﬁdence are very important for one?s career, and these meetings can help in both. Nineteen [7 underrepresented females, 3 African American females, 1 African male) undergraduate students] have participated in this and other projects during the academic year 2016-2020. Among these 5 undergraduate students are mainly involved in the NSF project. A new eﬀort in my group has been the involvement of high school students in research activities. To inspire students the PI and his group have presented a chemical demonstration to the students and faculties of Woodvale School in January 2020. 

Improving researchers? ability to exploit capacity and knowledge brings broader impacts within and beyond the immediate subject areas.   The present project will spur new collaborations and educational activities for undergraduate research, teaching, training, and sharing of data with a larger community of researchers.   New modes of research collaboration can be developed to further UL-L contributions to the ?grand challenges? facing society.
